prediction: The commission urged that European consumers keep buying lamb from British farms until the scientific results were available. "The commission is saying that we do not believe the risks are so great as to warrant a ban," she said, adding that there were scientific doubts about whether the prion disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, could spread to other animals. "The commission considers there is insufficient evidence to ban sheep meat from Britain because of B.S.E." Mrs. Shields said. Mrs. Shields said the commission had advised Britain that it must increase the number of lambs tested. The Department of the Environment has said that testing in Scotland and Ireland, where the first B.S.E. outbreaks have been found, should begin next week, but Mrs. Shields said the commission believed testing could begin immediately. A total of 48 sheep so far have been found to have the B.S.E. prion. Tests are being conducted to find out whether the prion is transmitted to other animals. Britain announced a month ago that it was testing 33,000 sheep and a similar number of sheep from neighboring countries. But since B.S.E. was first identified in sheep in March, no cases have been found in sheep in Britain. Mrs. Shields said the commission "does not accept the suggestion that British sheep are somehow less clean than sheep elsewhere in Europe," adding that British farmers were also subject to rules to protect consumers.
